description: {"blocks":[{"key":"becl1","text":"CUT\u0026RUN (Cleavage Under Targets and Release Using Nuclease) offers a novel approach ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"11rap","text":"to pursue epigenetics. The method is designed to map genome wide transcription factor ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ljoo","text":"binding sites, chromatin-associated complexes, and histone variants and post-translational ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"386bm","text":"modifications.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eol4p","text":"Here we provide an updated CUT\u0026RUN protocol that incorporates two variants, one is optimized to further reduce background noise which especially helps when working with low cell numbers and abundant antigens.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ci2ch","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"e40q4","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fol28","text":"In CUT\u0026RUN is performed in situ on immobilized, intact cells without crosslinking. DNA fragmentation is achieved using micrococcal nuclease that is fused to Protein A and/or Protein G (pA/G-MNase). The fusion protein is directed to the desired target through binding of the Protein A/G moiety to the Fc region of an antibody bound to the target. DNA under the target is subsequently cleaved and released and the pA/G-MNase-antibody- chromatin complex is free to diffuse out of the cell. DNA cleavage products are extracted and then processed by next generation sequencing (NGS).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fhrqa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"31eoh","text":"All steps from live cells to sequencing-ready libraries can be performed in a single tube on the benchtop or a microwell in a high-throughput pipeline, and the entire procedure can be performed in one day. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B935F230016011EA9DED7B6BCF20C4C3","height":791,"id":243518,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"overview cut\u0026run.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/public/0a4fe9b7a11f73c8ba5166c11a7060d8420e56909f0bef279aef656fabd5f2ab/btss9xr6.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hp389xr6.jpg","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/hp379xr6.webp","width":531}}}}

How do I choose between both methods.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":124}],"data":{}},{"key":"6b4t5","text":"Why is the DNA yield so low?","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":28}],"data":{}},{"key":"djoqv","text":"How do I choose a primary antibody for CUT\u0026RUN or CUT\u0026Tag?","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":58}],"data":{}},{"key":"ev1v8","text":"Why do I need a negative control antibody for CUT\u0026RUN? samples?","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":9,"offset":0,"length":91}],"data":{}},{"key":"ck9aj","text":"Is it possible to adapt CUT\u0026RUN to RNA digestion can I denature the proteins in the CUT\u0026RUN product complexes by heat?","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":11,"offset":0,"length":107}],"data":{}},{"key":"8dsuu","text":"What is preferable for DNA extractions prior to library preparation: extraction using phenol-chloroform or affinity purification using a column?","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":12,"offset":0,"length":144}],"data":{}},{"key":"dt8g8","text":"Is it possible to do single-end instead of paired-end sequencing of the CUT\u0026RUN libraries?","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":13,"offset":0,"length":90}],"data":{}},{"key":"9k4ho","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3qah1","text":"","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jq22","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":14,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7dita","text":"What are the advantages and disadvantages of CUT\u0026RUN and CUT\u0026Tag compared to ChIP-seq? How do I choose between both methods.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37bqv","text":"Advantages of CUT\u0026RUN and CUT\u0026Tag compared to ChIP-seq are a better signal-to-noise ratio, higher sensitivity, a wider dynamic range, a lower requirement of sequencing reads and cell number.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbn25","text":"CUT\u0026Tag has the advantage that the sequencing primers are being attached to the cleaved DNA fragments and requires fewer library preparation steps than CUT\u0026RUN. No additional annealing is necessary. The method works particularly well for nucleosomal and tightly bound proteins. It has also been streamlined by the Henikoff lab into a protocol where the entire process takes place in one tube and high throughput variations amenable for automation are available.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2r2i9","text":"CUT\u0026RUN on the other hand is preferable for transcription factors and other less tightly bound DNA binding proteins that are sensitive to the higher salt concentration in CUT\u0026Tag necessary to prevent off-target tagmentation of accessible chromatin by Tn5. In addition, the spatial resolution of the MNase digestion is higher than that of the tagmentation, enabling a clearer footprint of the protein of interest.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2222j","text":"Why is the DNA yield so low?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"513ue","text":"CUT\u0026RUN and CUT\u0026Tag are performed using low cell numbers and the background signal is considerably lower than e.g. for ChIP. This can make reliable measurements of the DNA concentration using a fluorometric assay or by capillary electrophoresis challenging.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5mdsq","text":"To assess the success of the CUT\u0026RUN and CUT\u0026Tag methods it is recommended to include a reaction using an antibody against and abundant histone modification such as h4K27me ( ABIN6923144) or h4K4me3 ( ABIN2668472) as a positive control. DNA fragments prepared using such an antibody can be measured by capillary electrophoresis on a Bioanalyzer or Tapestation or fluorometrically on a Qubit or Nanodrop fluorometer.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":15,"offset":174,"length":12},{"key":16,"offset":200,"length":12}],"data":{}},{"key":"1oq6","text":"How do I choose a primary antibody for CUT\u0026RUN or CUT\u0026Tag?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0c8r","text":"Antibodies that are recommended for ChIP-seq do not necessarily work in CUT\u0026RUN in CUT\u0026Tag. In contrast to ChIP-seq, the antigen is generally in its native state without additional fixation. Unless an antibody has already been tested for CUT\u0026RUN/Tag, a recommendation for a method in which the antigen is expected to be in a native state is helpful, e.g. Immunofluorescence. Unless indicated otherwise, the recommended dilution for immunofluorescence is also a good starting point for the antibody’s concentration in CUT\u0026RUN/Tag.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"39gpv","text":"Why do I need a negative control antibody for CUT\u0026RUN? Why not just use a no-antibody control?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ejjr","text":"The MNase used for CUT\u0026RUN is an endo- and exonuclease that will unspecifically bind and cleave unprotected DNA in hyper-accessible DNA, e.g. in regions surrounding regulatory elements. Free MNase will preferentially cut DNA within these hyper-accessible regions, thus potentially causing false positives and increase the background signal in general.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"84rm5","text":"To avoid this undesired effect of untethered MNase, chromatin is randomly coated with the CUT\u0026RUN guinea pig anti-rabbit IgG negative control antibody ( ABIN6923140) prior to the addition of pAG-MNase ( ABIN6950951) to the samples. pAG-MNase is then tethered via its Protein A or Protein G portion to the antibody’s Fc fragment and background DNA fragmentation is dictated by the random antibody binding as opposed to the nuclease digestion of hyper-accessible DNA regions.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":17,"offset":152,"length":12},{"key":18,"offset":202,"length":12}],"data":{}},{"key":"b1n6k","text":"Can I replace the antibody negative control for CUT\u0026RUN using a knock-out (or knock-down) of my protein?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"929tt","text":"Both controls are useful but address different aspects of the experiment and are therefore not interchangeable.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3i6fe","text":"The CUT\u0026RUN guinea pig anti-rabbit IgG negative control antibody ( ABIN6923140) is used to establish a reference background for peak calling. This is necessary because of the sparse background signal in CUT\u0026RUN samples compared to ChIP-seq samples. The ko (or kd) control on the other hand gives an impression of unspecific binding of the antibody directed against the protein of interest to other proteins. It is useful to avoid identification of false positive signals.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":19,"offset":66,"length":12}],"data":{}},{"key":"55p01","text":"Do I need to use a secondary antibody for CUT\u0026RUN and CUT\u0026Tag?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2or60","text":"Depending on the host species and isotype of the antibody and the Protein A and/or Protein G MNase fusion protein, a secondary antibody may be necessary for MNase binding. Protein A has good high affinity to all rabbit IgG antibodies but low affinity to rat, goat and sheep IgG isotype antibodies and certain mouse IgG antibody subclasses, in particular IgG1. Protein G on the other hand binds well to the Fc region of mouse, goat, sheep, and most rat IgG. Its affinity to rabbit IgG however is lower than that of Protein A. When using pAG-MNase introduced with the improved CUT\u0026RUN protocol it is therefore generally not necessary to use a secondary antibody. Use of the pA-MNase of the original protocol however might require the use of a secondary antibody raised in rabbit to assure efficient binding of the fusion protein to the antibody.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmjfn","text":"For CUT\u0026Tag a secondary antibody is recommended to increase the local concentration of Fc fragment binding site in the vicinity of the intended transposition site around the antigen of interest. This step is necessary to increase the specific signal.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9cpfo","text":"One of my antibodies is mouse. Has your pAG-MNase good affinity for mouse antibodies, or do you advise to use a rabbit anti-mouse secondary antibody?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6075","text":"The pAG-MNase will work well with your murine antibody. The addition of protein G to the MNase is primarily to accomodate the use of mouse IgG1 monoclonal antibodies that bind poorly to protein A. The other IgG isotypes bind well to either protein A or protein G.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"nia2","text":"Should I include heterologous spike-in DNA for quantitation?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4hb3","text":"Our protocol is largely based on the improved CUT\u0026RUN protocol. Here, the authors show that accurate quantitation is possible using heterologous spike-in DNA or carry-overE. coliDNA from the pAG-MNase purification. Therefore, the addition of heterologous spike-in DNA is not necessary.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":171,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bc417","text":"Is it possible to fix the cells prior to immobilization?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3srkh","text":"It is possible to fix your samples, e.g. to avoid dissociation of larger protein complex from the DNA during the course for the experiment. You can either follow your established cross-linking procedure or mild cross-linking conditions using formaldehyde at a lower concentration of 0.1%. Cross-linking at 1% formaldehyde can actually reduce signal, possibly due to epitope masking. In these cases, a lower concentration of cross-linker is preferable.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7g42c","text":"Is it possible to use the antibodies-online CUT\u0026RUN product sets with plant tissue samples?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fuubn","text":"The CUT\u0026RUN method can be applied to plant tissue samples. An essential step in addition to those lined out in the protocol is the generation of spheroblasts so that it becomes possible to permeabilize the plasma membrane for the application of the antibodies and the MNase fusion protein. Alternatively, use isolated nuclei as sample material.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7i4k3","text":"The CUT\u0026RUN rabbit anti-h4K27me3 positive control antibody ( ABIN6923144) and the CUT\u0026RUN guinea pig anti-rabbit IgG negative control antibody ( ABIN6923140) as well as the ConA beads ( ABIN6923139orABIN6952467) are suitable for use with plant samples.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":20,"offset":60,"length":12},{"key":21,"offset":144,"length":12},{"key":22,"offset":185,"length":12},{"key":23,"offset":199,"length":11}],"data":{}},{"key":"8aq3s","text":"Is it possible to adapt CUT\u0026RUN to RNA binding proteins?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6dec7","text":"The MNase used for CUT\u0026RUN also accepts RNA as substrate so it might be possible to adapt the CUT\u0026RUN protocol for use on RNA binding proteins.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19ac7","text":"RNA in the cytoplasm will attract the degradation machinery if it is lacking the 5' cap and the 3' poly-A tail. Therefore, I would suggest to use work with isolated nuclei. This has the additional benefit, that you can omit the digitonin in the buffers, which is used to replace the cholesterol and permeabilize the cell membrane. The isolated nuclei may then be immobilized using magnetic ConA beads like for a CUT\u0026RUN experiment. An antibody against the protein of interest is added and subsequently the pAG-MNase is tethered to the antibody, thus bringing the MNase into proximity of the RNA of interest. Isolated RNA can then be reverse transcribed into cDNA to produce your sequencing library.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0tvn","text":"In order to dispose of any contaminating DNA include a DNase treatment in the protocol subsequently to the RNA-prep and before the library prep. Normalization based on theE. coliDNA carried over with the MNase or a spike-in DNA is not an option in this case. Instead, consider using the total read numbers to normalize across samples or include a reference RNA of a known concentration.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":171,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34bej","text":"Instead of the proteinase K digestion can I denature the proteins in the CUT\u0026RUN product complexes by heat?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ctl62","text":"We recommend against this option: the DNA of interest is at his point present in a complex consisting of the DNA, the antigen, the corresponding antibody, and the pAG-MNase. Boiling this complex will likely precipitate the DNA together with denatured protein. This will also primarily affect the short CUT\u0026RUN products and not the larger DNA molecules, leading to a decreased signal to noise ratio in your library and potentially also reducing the library’s complexity. This effect is further exacerbated because of the lower melting temperature of these short molecules compared to the longer contaminating DNA molecules.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3qd4v","text":"What is preferable for DNA extractions prior to library preparation: extraction using phenol-chloroform or affinity purification using a column?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7dscp","text":"A potential issue when using SPRI beads for the DNA fragment clean-up is the carry-over of active Proteinase K, which can interfere with the downstream PCR amplification. Therefore, a phenol-chloroform extraction is preferable to assure complete denaturation of Proteinase K.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1iie0","text":"Is it possible to do single-end instead of paired-end sequencing of the CUT\u0026RUN libraries?","type":"header-three","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8l0ul","text":"Single-end sequencing instead of paired-end sequencing is possible. However, it has drawbacks compared to paired-end sequencing: (i) For abundant targets like histone marks or transcription factors a large number of binding sites is expected. Paired-end sequencing facilitates unambiguous mapping to the correct genomic position. This additional information reduces the necessary sequencing depth. (ii) MNase will digest the target DNA until the section covered by the protein of interest. Paired-end sequencing will reveal this footprint while the information is lost in single-end sequencing.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3A08B76AD1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/resources/17/5366/cutrun/#faq1"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3A08B6F2D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/resources/17/5366/cutrun/#faq2"}},"10":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3A08B6C6D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/resources/17/5366/cutrun/#faq11"}},"11":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3A08B681D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/resources/17/5366/cutrun/#faq12"}},"12":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3A08B6A4D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/resources/17/5366/cutrun/#faq13"}},"13":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3A08B714D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/resources/17/5366/cutrun/#faq14"}},"14":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":null,"entityMap":null}},"15":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"542A63F2D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/accessory-reagent/6923144/CUTRUN+Positive+Control"}},"16":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"542A62C2D1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/antibody/2668472/anti-Histone+3+H3+H3K4me3+antibody"}},"17":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"542A630ED1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/accessory-reagent/6923140/CUTRUN+Negative+Control"}},"18":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"542A635BD1F911ECA5680A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.antibodies-online.com/enzyme/6950952/CUTANA+pAG-MNase+for+ChIC+CUTRUN+Assays"}},"19":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE"
